title-group.subtitle: The Role of Beliefs in Firms’ Responses to Regulation

author-notes.corresp: Kenneth A. Dubin, Visiting Professor, Social Law, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, c/ Madrid, 126-128, 28903 Madrid, Spain Email: ken.dubin@uc3m.es

abstract.p: Firms may find competitive adjustment difficult because they are hamstrung by rigid labor market rules. However, such difficulties may also be caused by conflicts between strategic choices in the management of human capital and the opportunities and limitations created by a given regulatory framework. This latter possibility has been almost totally ignored in the debate regarding the urgency and content of labor market reforms in countries whose labor market institutions have been labeled as “rigid” by international experts. This article uses the results of qualitative interviews with Spanish employers to suggest that strategic choices may be far more important in determining the consequences of labor market institutions than is generally recognized. I show that these choices are often the result of beliefs about how labor market institutions should work. These findings suggest that supposedly “neutral” calls for greater efficiency in labor market institutions are really arguments about the relative appropriateness of different expectations regarding how firms should pursue adjustment, expectations that are directly related both to the relative balance of power between employers and workers and to the structure of their relationship. In other words, the phrase “politics of labor market reform” should be understood to refer not only to the political consequences of reforms but also to the inherently political nature of the reforms themselves.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: If economic globalization implies a permanent process of competitive adjustment, does it also mean the inevitable degradation of collective rights at work? Employers and their allies frequently argue that the relaxation of limitations on their discretion to manage—the freedom to hire, fire, and redeploy workers as they wish—is indispensable to the future competitiveness of the advanced industrial countries.1 This article takes issue with this claim through an analysis of firms’ competitive adjustment strategies in Spain, a country that is widely considered to have among the most restrictive labor market rules anywhere.2

Contrary to expectations, firms that engage workers collectively are often able to adjust more effectively than those that go to great lengths to limit collective voice at work. These results are surprising for two reasons: first, because Spanish labor regulations are generally considered to be a significant obstacle to competiveness; and second, because most observers believe that Spanish employers have developed a set of relatively effective strategies for evading these regulations, albeit with important negative effects for aggregate social welfare (i.e., high rates of unemployment and precarious work). My research shows that the central obstacle to more effective adjustment strategies in Spain is not the regulatory framework itself but rather how firms choose to respond to the challenges and incentives constituted by it.

The employer choices described in this article are largely motivated by the beliefs of senior managers rather than by the structural position of their respective firms or the composition of their workforces. This is a result with important implications for debates about the reform of labor markets and labor relations systems in Spain and beyond. If employers’ perceptions of labor market rigidities are driven at least as much by beliefs as they are by some objective incompatibility between the dictates of competition and the regulatory framework, then employer demands for regulatory reforms are best understood as ideologically motivated preferences regarding the distribution of power in the workplace. In other words, claims for the technical superiority of one or another labor market reform proposal are inextricably connected to efforts to privilege a particular model of corporate governance and to discredit others. The evidence presented here reminds us that demands for greater employer discretion in deploying human capital are neither neutral nor, critically, indispensable for competitive success.

This article is not the first to question assertions that productivity-stifling rigidities in labor market institutions are to blame for Spain’s exceptionally high rates of temporary employment and unemployment: heterodox economists dispute the claim that Spanish labor market institutions generate obstacles to creating and sustaining quality jobs and competitive firms; jurists defend the principles of collective regulation of the employment relationship and limits on dismissal without cause, which are enshrined in existing rules, and reject reforms proposed by mainstream economists as tantamount to an abandonment of these principles. Although the protagonists in this debate disagree about the “rigidity” of Spanish labor market institutions, none disputes that labor market institutions have a direct impact on firms’ choices of human resource strategy; in other words, that strategic options flow relatively seamlessly from institutions.

Recent work in the comparative political economy of labor markets calls this shared belief into question by demonstrating that labor market actors may reshape or even ignore formal institutions that prove unsuitable to their collective purposes.3 How they do so is in no way predetermined by the institutions themselves, but rather depends on their strategic objectives, the balance of power between the actors involved, their beliefs about the nature of their relationships, and their understandings of the formal institutional framework within which they operate. For example, in an interesting corrective to the varieties of capitalism literature,4 Herrmann (2008) has demonstrated that pharmaceutical companies are capable of successfully pursuing human resource strategies that go against the grain of the rules and norms attributed to each nation’s labor market institutions.5 If German, Italian, and British firms can deploy strategies that contravene the incentives structured by whole constellations of institutions constituting particular varieties of capitalism, surely Spanish employers can design human resource strategies that sidestep supposed institutional rigidities to achieve world-class standards of labor productivity.

Even those who argue that Spanish labor institutions are extraordinarily rigid would not deny that such alternatives exist. However, they would maintain, this misses the point: employers pursuing such strategies are few and far between, precisely because labor market institutions are relatively authoritative. Their critics, meanwhile, would respond that such strategies are rare because of broader problems in Spanish product and service markets.

Indeed, restoring employment and encouraging employers to pursue greater investments in human capital will surely require reforms that extend well beyond the regulation of the Spanish workplace itself. To name just a few: reducing transaction costs associated with opening a business; promoting greater competition in business services; facilitating access to financing, especially for smaller enterprises; and equilibrating the balance between social protection and incentives for the unemployed to improve their employability and willingness to accept work.6 Nevertheless, the claim that at least some of Spain’s labor market problems lie in the regulation of the workplace itself is hardly controversial.

This article offers a new perspective on this debate using results from interviews with Spanish employers across a range of sectors regarding their beliefs and experiences with labor market institutions. As the evidence presented here suggests, the commonplace that Spanish labor market regulations are extraordinarily rigid deserves far more skeptical scrutiny (and empirical testing) than it has received to date.7 This evidence also reveals important limitations in the reform proposals of conventional economists as well as their critics. Despite many points of disagreement, their diagnoses and proposed solutions share a common limitation: an overly narrow view of how labor market regulations shape behavior that leaves little space for such important mechanisms as culture, beliefs, and politics.

As a result, they fail to explain why some firms find current employment regulations to be rigid while other similarly situated employers are able to adjust human resources successfully. Do successful firms outwit poorly designed institutions, or do failing firms refuse to play by the institutional rules? Or, perhaps, do the determinants of success and failure lie entirely outside the realm of labor market institutions? The research presented here suggests that the degree to which participants and observers describe Spanish labor market regulations as rigid depends very much on prior understandings of how labor markets should work. These understandings, in turn, shape firms’ choices of human resources strategies, the solutions they develop to the challenges posed by labor market institutions, and critically, their abilities to adjust across the business cycle.

The implications of this research speak to issues of labor market regulation far beyond Spain. If institutions result from the accretion of multiple political battles, then the incentives they offer are highly unlikely to be univocal.8 And if institutional incentives are ambiguous, employers have to make difficult choices about what to do under conditions of great uncertainty. How they come to these decisions thus becomes critical to understanding how labor market institutions work in practice and what we might expect from any particular set of reforms. Moreover, employer choices have important consequences for the balance of power in the workplace and the distribution of opportunities and rewards in society. The question of how proposed labor market reforms might influence these choices is therefore profoundly political: different reforms privilege different employer choices, which in effect, I will argue, means privileging some beliefs about how institutions should work over others.

The article will proceed as follows. In the next section, I briefly summarize conventional explanations for Spain’s labor market problems, the principles underlying these respective arguments, and the solutions they propose. Section three details the problems facing Spanish employers in their own words, and section four develops an original typology of responses to these problems and the reasons underlying employers’ strategic choices. Section five clarifies the implications of these findings for the Spanish case, examines debates about labor market reforms more generally, and is followed by a brief conclusion.

sec.title: II. Explaining Poor Labor Market Outcomes
sec.p: Spain’s unemployment rate in the first quarter of 2011 was an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD)–leading 21.3 percent. Unfortunately, Spaniards are quite familiar with such bleak numbers. In 1985, unemployment reached 21.5 percent, falling only modestly to 15.9 percent at the peak of recovery in 1990 and reaching an all-time high of 24.6 percent in 1994. Even after a decade of intensive economic growth that preceded the current crisis, the unemployment rate scarcely fell below 8 percent.9 Adding insult to injury, Spain’s rate of temporary employment has also been the highest in the European Union (EU) for more than two decades.10

Most conventional accounts attribute these problems to flawed labor market institutions. High effective costs for layoffs are assumed to discourage employers from offering workers permanent contracts. Theoretically, employers can dismiss permanent employees with cause (economic, technological, or organizational changes) for 20 days of pay/year worked up to the equivalent of 24 months of salary. In practice, however, judges are reluctant to recognize causal dismissals; as a result, most workers receive 45 days/year up to 42 months of salary.11

Meanwhile, the structure of collective bargaining and worker representation in Spanish firms is said to dampen job creation by raising wage costs and complicating companies’ efforts to pursue competitive adjustment through work reorganization rather than through adjustments in employment levels. Collective bargaining in Spain is predominantly organized by sector in separate agreements in each of fifty provinces. Agreements are automatically applied to all workplaces within the bargaining unit and provide a strict floor for firm-level wages and wage structures, job classifications, and working hours. Sectoral bargaining agents for workers are selected on the basis of elections for worker representatives in firms with six or more employees.12 Given that the median voter in these elections has a permanent contract and that employers can reduce employment levels cheaply by not renewing temporary contracts, sectoral bargaining agents appear to have few incentives to engage in wage restraint.13 Major changes in workplace organization must be negotiated with worker representatives in the firm. Like dismissal rules, these requirements are also claimed to encourage employers to adjust through employment levels, in this case to avoid lengthy and potentially costly bargaining over work rules.14

In sum, the conventional wisdom argues that the combination of expensive dismissals for permanent workers and restrictive rules governing collective relations at the sectoral and firm levels discourage job creation and, in particular, the creation of permanent employment. However, these institutional features of the Spanish labor market are not sufficiently different from those in other countries to explain the country’s singularly high rates of temporary employment.

Early attempts to explain this gap focused on demand-side factors: namely, an employment structure weighted toward low-skilled, easily replaceable jobs in volatile sectors like tourism and construction.15 In an important correction, Polavieja16 argues that high rates of segmentation between permanent and temporary workers exist across a wide variety of job functions, including those where important levels of firm-specific human capital and high monitoring costs would, according to much theorizing in both economics and sociology, encourage employers to offer more stable contracts in order to motivate worker effort through seniority wages.17 He attributes this Spanish anomaly to both institutional rigidities as well as structural dynamics—the combination of high levels of legal protections for permanent workers and high unemployment rates. Under these circumstances, employers may efficiently motivate even highly skilled temporary workers by dangling before them the possibility of obtaining a permanent contract.

This theory rests in part on the existence of buffer effects between permanent and temporary workers. Where, as in Spain, temporary employment is high and the cost difference between dismissing temporary and permanent workers is large, permanent workers’ fear of dismissal should be correspondingly low. This buffer is assumed to have a negative impact on permanent workers’ productivity.18 As a result, although high turnover of workers with firm-specific assets is costly, these costs may well be less than those of creating additional permanent workers: “[I]f the use of temporary contracts allow employers to extract greater levels of output from their professional workers than standard incentive schemes in long-term employment relationships, then there is simply no reason why temporary employment should be confined to low-skilled jobs.”19

These findings constitute the point of departure for the labor market reforms proposed by 100 influential economists in April 2009.20 They argue that current labor market institutions encourage firms to pursue competitive adjustment through levels of employment, giving rise to both widespread fixed-term contracting and large fluctuations in the unemployment rate as economic conditions change: “…existing regulation induces firms to respond to economic fluctuations through labor turnover, rather than looking for alternatives such as changes in workplace organization.” They maintain that replacing Spain’s numerous, state-defined employment contracts with a single contract offering gradually increasing severance would eliminate the divide between temporary and permanent employees. They also believe a single contract would encourage employers to make bigger investments in human capital, which, in turn, would raise productivity and also make employers more reluctant to dismiss workers. They also propose reforms in collective bargaining rules to make it easier for firm-level negotiators to opt out of clauses from sectoral agreements that are now automatically extended to all firms within the sectoral/geographical bargaining unit. Such a change, they argue, would enable employers to adjust wages and working conditions more quickly, encouraging internal flexibility rather than reliance on employment levels as a key to competitive transformation.

A minority of economists dissents from this conventional wisdom, arguing that Spanish labor regulations are an obstacle only for those employers who choose low-road competitive strategies, and, in any event, such employers are generally able to circumvent much of the formal regulatory framework.21 These economists believe that high levels of temporary work and unemployment are the result of the state’s long neglect of industrial policies that would encourage or even oblige employers to invest in higher value-added activities and its underinvestment in social programs (like childcare and aid for dependent persons) that would create an enormous number of well-paying, secure jobs.

A similar debate plays out within the community of Spanish labor and employment law22 scholars; however, the efficiency concerns that dominate the economists’ analyses share the stage with concerns about equity. Labor law’s claim to distinction as a field of theory and practice rests on the contention that contracts between employers and workers are not contracts among equals: labor law’s raison d’être is the protection of the weaker party.23 Efficiency concerns are not absent from Spanish labor law;24 however, workers’ right to bargain collectively and restrictions on employers’ abilities to change workers’ job status or working conditions unilaterally without proper cause are understood by most jurists not as “rigidities” but rather as fundamental building blocks for a just and equitable society.25

Not surprisingly, then, the minority opinion within the community of labor law scholars is precisely that which argues that efficiency concerns should be the point of departure in policy debates regarding labor market reforms.26 Most Spanish labor law jurists limit their proposals to measures that will improve the functioning of existing institutions (e.g., incremental reforms in contracting rules, work rules, collective bargaining structures, and procedures for dispute resolution and labor administration) without calling into question the overall balance of power between employers and workers or the basic principles set out in the Spanish Constitution, the Workers’ Statute or the 1985 Organic Law for Union Freedom.

A group of more than 700 labor law scholars, heterodox economists, and sociologists published a response to the 100 economists, arguing, unsurprisingly, that the jobs crisis in Spain had nothing whatsoever to do with labor market regulation.27

disp-quote.p: Encouraging layoffs without cause or judicial control is not the way to reform a labor market in the context of a new, more productive economic model. …The result would be to generalize the precariousness of work and the reduction of layoff costs. …It is absolutely incongruent to take advantage of the present situation to reduce or eliminate social rights.

sec.p: Central to this argument is the belief that employers who lay off workers without cause must be penalized. Adherence to this principle explains the radical rejection of the 100 economists’ proposal for a single contract category that can be ended for any reason at all (except for violations of fundamental rights). These scholars also reject the 100 economists’ proposal to facilitate firm-level opt-outs from sectoral collective bargaining agreements on the grounds that this would effectively undermine the central principle of workers’ right to voice in the setting of workplace conditions, particularly given the high number of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Spain where there are no workplace representatives.

The interdisciplinary debate regarding the future of labor market regulation in Spain is thus complicated by contrasting sets of first principles. Economists do, of course, care about justice and equity, particularly when framed in terms of aggregate welfare; however, they also believe that more efficient outcomes are generally more equitable, and, ipso facto, just. Hence, their analysis is primarily concerned with identifying the relative consequences of existing institutions and their theoretical alternatives for both levels of employment and firms’ abilities to respond to market signals. Likewise, most Spanish jurists understand that labor market rules are increasingly important for firm success; yet, they also believe that significant changes to these rules can generate both uncertainty about rights and roles and efficiency-sapping conflict (in firms, in the courts, and in the streets), thus counseling restraint.28 This worldview explains jurists’ critical concern with ensuring that extant rights and obligations and the procedural norms that underlie their application are followed, both under the present scheme and in any process of institutional adjustment.29 It also helps explain why so many economists find the reform proposals of jurists to be lacking in ambition. The law, as Bourdieu has noted, is inherently conservative.30

Differences regarding first principles between the dominant camps within labor economics and labor law, respectively, have a significant impact on their preferences for both the substance and process of reforming labor markets. Substantively, they differ regarding the links between efficiency and equity in the design of labor market institutions; procedurally, they differ regarding the efficacy of radical changes in achieving their preferred ends.

These differences are clearly illustrated by the one issue about which both groups do agree—that the structure of collective bargaining needs to be adjusted to promote greater use of internal rather than external flexibility.31 Substantively, the critics of the 100 economists demand that unions be fully involved in any firm-level negotiations over decoupling from sectoral agreements, whereas the economists’ proposal is less demanding, particularly with respect to smaller firms. Procedurally, the economists advocate legal reforms with or without the support of the social partners, whereas the counterproposal’s signatories insist that any changes in the rules governing collective bargaining be negotiated. This insistence on a negotiated reform brings to the fore a thorny reality described by a leading labor law scholar:
The obstacles to the utilization of agile mechanisms for internal flexibility in our labor relations system today are not to be found substantively in the legal framework…[but rather in] specific customs established with the passage of time in collective bargaining agreements. It is precisely in the moment of discussing the adaption of the contents of these agreements to the internal flexibility requirements of the firm where we perceive the largest degree of disagreement between the social interlocutors [leading to a renewed dependence on temporary contracting, outsourcing, and dependent contractors].32

This article contributes to the debate regarding the appropriate direction of labor market reform in Spain—and beyond—by opening the black box defined by these “customs,” that is, habitual ways of solving regulatory problems in the workplace. In the remaining sections, I offer a stylized description of the various ways Spanish employers address regulatory challenges in pursuing their preferred human resource strategies, identify the origins of these solutions, and discuss their implications.

sec.title: III. Paths to Human Capital Adjustment: The View of Human Resources Managers
A. The Research
sec.p: This paper reports results from approximately thirty formal interviews and more than twenty less structured conversations with senior human resources managers of firms from the following sectors: agribusiness, banking, broadcast media, chemicals and pharmaceuticals, construction, construction materials, food and beverage, transportation, hospitality, logistics, professional services, oil and gas, telecommunications, and telematics. Firm staff in Spain ranged in size from under 200 to several thousand. A few firms had no works council (required by law should workers seek to organize one in firms with fifty or more employees) whereas others were almost entirely unionized (afiliados). Some firms had their own collective bargaining agreement (or multiple plant-level agreements), whereas others were subject to sectoral agreements negotiated at the provincial or national level. The sample includes Spanish family-owned firms as well as Spanish and foreign multinational corporations. Corroboration for certain claims made by employers was obtained through three focus groups and many informal discussions held with union leaders, labor inspectors, and small business administrators (gestorías).

Interview subjects were identified through their relatively intense participation—and in some cases, leadership—in various forums for the exchange of ideas among human resources and labor relations professionals and through personal contacts. The interviews were organized around a semistructured questionnaire that ensured comparability of answers across the sample while providing extensive opportunity for detailed follow-up around specific issues. Interviews lasted at least an hour and as many as three; approximately 90 percent lasted between ninety minutes and two hours. The sample is not representative of human resources managers in Spain, nor is it in any way statistically significant; it does, however, provide considerable insight into the most innovative thinking and practice regarding the limits and possibilities of the existing regulatory framework—precisely the issue on which this article seeks to shed light.

Subjects were asked to define the challenges their firms face in the context of the current crisis, the ways in which the crisis has altered their human capital strategies, and the central obstacles—both formal and informal—to putting these new strategies into place. The results reveal that firms’ adjustment strategies in the face of the current crisis are significantly influenced by their beliefs regarding how the labor market should work, which, in turn, influence their understandings of how existing institutions work in practice.

sec.title: B. The Challenges Facing Spanish Employers
sec.p: In a nutshell, the current crisis has pushed the firms interviewed for this project to adjust their human capital strategies in two broad ways: workforce reductions (nonrenewal of temporary contracts, layoffs, and outsourcing) and productivity improvements. These employers are seeking to enhance productivity by moderating salaries, by increasing worker motivation, and by augmenting flexibility through changes in workforce deployment. The particular forms taken by these strategies vary notably across the sample, as do the ways they have been implemented and the degree of success obtained. Not surprisingly, all those interviewed complain about labor market rigidities that complicate their efforts. However, the content of these complaints and the degree to which they view these rigidities as a real impediment to firm competitiveness vary markedly. Differences in strategy, implementation approaches, and success rates are closely related to the ways in which managers understand the regulatory framework that governs Spanish labor and employment relations. Differences in these understandings closely track the differences in first principles underlying the debate among economists and labor law scholars regarding labor market reforms.

sec.title: C. Workforce Reduction Strategies
sec.p: Employer concerns about obstacles to pursuing workforce reductions in Spain exhibit far less variety than do those about internal flexibility. Indeed, employer opinions regarding dismissals dovetail with the criticisms leveled by economists: layoffs of longtime permanent workers are expensive, collective layoffs (EREs) take too long to pursue, and certain groups of workers (works council representatives, pregnant women, and mothers of young children) enjoy near-total job protection. Moreover, situations that in theory reduce the costs of layoffs with cause—significant economic losses, changes in technology or workplace organization that make jobs redundant, or poor employee performance—are, in practice, difficult to prove in court.33 Employers can expect that individual workers and their representatives will denounce claims of legitimate cause in the labor courts, delaying their implementation and introducing a great deal of uncertainty regarding the final outcome; many judges view even carefully documented disciplinary layoffs skeptically.34

EREs require the ability and willingness to pay indemnizations higher than those established for layoffs with cause; indeed, gaining works council acquiescence to a collective layoff often requires payments that exceed the legally mandated cost of individual layoffs without cause—forty-five days per year up to the equivalent of forty-two months of salary plus a thirty-day mandatory notification period. EREs also involve multiple layers of time-consuming negotiations.35 In the first instance, employers must seek agreement from the works council, which, in turn, will often prefer to ask the rank and file to approve any negotiated settlement. When works councils dispute claims about the need for layoffs, employers will often look to involve sectoral union officials (federaciones) in the negotiations. Opinions regarding the utility of this approach are mixed. On the one hand, most employers have found the federations to be more professional than workplace representatives. Given their contacts with multiple firms, they often have a better understanding of market conditions as well as sectoral trends (and thus, the urgency of the changes sought) and of the relative generosity of the proposed indemnizations.

However, several factors affect the willingness of union officials to support employers’ layoff proposals. First, inter-union battles for worker support can generate bidding wars even at the sectoral level. Many times smaller, more radical unions seize on collective layoffs as an opportunity to gain support by painting the main unions, Comisiones Obreras and Unión General de Trabajadores (CC.OO. and UGT) as timid; as a result, union officials often recognize privately the reasonableness of an employer’s proposals but are reluctant to support them publicly. A related problem frequently emerges at big industrial plants outside large cities. In these cases, employers are vulnerable to political grandstanding by unions seeking to demonstrate their ability to defend local workers’ jobs.36 Finally, union officials are often reluctant to challenge the positions of works council members for fear of losing their allegiance. Works councils in Spain are legally independent of unions; union officials thus cannot force their local members to accept an employer proposal or even a union counterproposal. Because a union’s institutional privileges (seats at sectoral bargaining tables, control of training funds that are a key component of their operational budgets, access to state subsidies, etc.) are determined by the number of works council delegates who run successfully for their posts under that organization’s colors, union officials legitimately fear that publicly supporting employer proposals rejected by works councils may lead to a loss of delegates in the next round of shop-floor elections.37

Given the complications associated with collective layoffs, many employers prefer to negotiate a series of individual layoffs just below the limits the law sets for collective procedures. This strategy is obviously less politically complicated than an ERE and avoids signaling economic problems to competitors; however, according to employers, it has three drawbacks. First, when the total number of desired layoffs is high, it can slow the process of adjustment even more than an ERE because the number of workers that can be laid off in any three-month period is limited to less than 10 percent of the workforce. Second, while such layoffs need not be negotiated with worker representatives, refusal to do so may well generate considerable ill will and even, in some cases, outright conflict. A third, related risk is that if workers or their representatives denounce these practices to the Labor Inspectorate, the strategy may be declared fraudulent, leading to substantial fines and even a court-imposed obligation to reinstate dismissed workers.

Despite these challenges, few of the interviewed managers were particularly concerned with the costs of adjusting staffing levels. As one manager said, voicing a widely echoed sentiment, “Given the employment problems in Spain, free layoffs are neither realistic nor appropriate.”38 Clearly, firms would prefer to pay less for layoffs. At the same time, many managers were quick to point out that the 2002 labor market reform made possible the immediate dismissal (without cause) of all but a handful of specifically protected workers (works council members; mothers of young children) with perfectly predictable costs. For larger firms with the concomitant financial resources, gaining the ability to pursue individual layoffs rapidly and with predictable costs resolved their most important complaint regarding the regulation of dismissals.39 In fact, several managers commented that the main employer association’s Confederación Española de Organizaciones Empresariales (CEOE) persistent, noisy complaints about layoff costs speak more to the organization’s inability to aggregate more complex employer demands than they do to the actual priorities of most employers.40

Caveats like these aside, layoff costs for workers with substantial tenure are, in comparative terms, relatively expensive. Clearly, one important strategy for reducing layoff costs is to maintain a significant cushion of temporary workers whose contracts are simply not renewed should market conditions change. However, given the similarities of Spanish labor market institutions to several other European countries, the cost differential between dismissing permanent and temporary workers cannot fully explain the country’s exceptionally high temporary employment rate. Thus, when we examine firms’ productivity strategies, we must begin by discussing the role of temporary employment in workforce productivity.

sec.title: D. Pathways to Productivity
sec.p: Productivity concerns are a key factor in many firms’ decisions to rely heavily on temporary contracts. Many of the employers interviewed feel that the regulatory framework (law, collective bargaining rules, and the role of worker representatives in the firm) is far less flexible with respect to internal—or functional—flexibility than it is with respect to external—or contracting—flexibility. Although the formal rules limiting flexibility in job assignments and scheduling for temporary and permanent employees are the same, in practice, temporary employees (especially those who seek to have their contracts renewed) are far more likely to accept changes in working conditions than their permanent counterparts. This also means that temporary employees often perform tasks that are formally reserved for higher salary grades.41

Employers clearly understand that temporary contracting increases—at least in the short term—external, internal, and salary flexibility. However, firms are far less able to measure the productivity costs of temporary employment in terms of motivation, training, and skills, which leads to underestimating its true costs. Gaining proficiency in executing even the most simple of tasks requires time and knowledge of organizational routines and networks. With temporary employment so widespread, many of these workers are clearly performing far more than simple tasks; their productivity is likely to be low without time on the job and training. However, when firms rely heavily on temporary employment, they and their employees have weak incentives to invest in firm-specific skills; moreover, if turnover among temporary workers is high, such investments will often be lost before they can be amortized.42

With respect to motivation, however, many employers echo the words of Polavieja (2006), arguing that temporary employees are often more motivated than permanent workers because they feel more vulnerable than their peers, particularly those with considerable tenure. This brings us to the nub of the problem for enhancing labor productivity in Spain. Having consolidated an approach to human resources management that exploits the divisions between temporary and permanent workers, many firms encounter enormous difficulties when seeking to put alternatives in place. Temporary contracting—first facilitated in 1984 by the Socialists as a way of increasing labor market participation rates for youth, women, and other outsiders—eventually consolidated a peculiarly Spanish policy of adjustment, “flexibility on the margins.”43 Flexibility on the margins is typically understood as a strategy of external flexibility. However, as we have just seen, temporary contracting is the cornerstone of many employers’ strategies for increasing productivity through internal flexibility.

Not surprisingly, then, most prescriptive analyses of the Spanish labor market offer proposals for institutional innovations with an eye toward encouraging firms to adopt tactics that do not rely so heavily on the level and composition of employment.44 Often obscured within this debate is the fact that some firms from sectors in which human capital strategies are key to competitiveness manage to succeed across the business cycle without massive recourse to temporary employment.45 This neglect suggests that we need to develop a fuller appreciation of how firm strategies interact with the formal regulatory framework: specifically, it would be helpful to know more about what alternatives exist to the contract-based model of productivity management and how robust each of these alternatives is across the business cycle.

Clarifying whether the relative successes and failures of firms’ human capital adjustment strategies are the product of labor market regulations, strategic choices, or other factors beyond their control is obviously critical for determining the appropriate direction of policy reforms. However, such data is largely absent from the mainstream debate regarding labor market reforms in Spain and elsewhere. If firms’ failures to adjust are perhaps more attributable to strategic choices than to the limitations of the institutional framework in which they operate, then our diagnoses of their competitive problems may be radically misguided. Given that these diagnoses inform proposals for labor market reforms that can significantly affect not only labor market performance but also the distribution of power within the firm and the capacities of workers and employers for collective action, the political—as well as economic—implications of how we define the obstacles to firms’ human capital strategies are enormous.

sec.title: E. A Typology of Regulatory Solutions to Human Capital Challenges
sec.p: In order to engage this question, this section offers a stylized description of two broad categories of human capital management strategies and four different kinds of regulatory solutions firms pursue as they seek to put one of these human capital strategies into place. This discussion will reveal that employers’ beliefs about the rigidities of the labor market are very much shaped by the human capital strategies and regulatory solutions they embrace and their adequacies or limitations across the entire business cycle. In many cases, criticisms of the regulatory framework tell us more about a firm’s failure to adapt its regulatory strategy to new economic realities and institutional incentives than about the regulatory framework itself.

Many of the rigidities that employers complain about are in fact rigidities of their own creation: during the recent decade of growth, many Spanish firms were able to pursue their preferred human capital strategy while paying little regard to the underlying logic of formal labor market institutions. Having established strategies that are difficult to sustain across the business cycle, it is not surprising that many managers understand their difficulties to be a product of the regulatory framework itself rather than previous management decisions. However, the supposed rigidities of the Spanish regulatory framework do not prevent other firms from putting in place significant productivity improvements through measures other than contract (external) flexibility, even when doing so necessitates important corrections in their human capital strategies.

This observation suggests an important limitation of extant models of human resources strategies. Typologies of human resources strategies in business studies have evolved toward an ever more fine-grained parsing of strategies according to underlying competitive strategies, the value and scarcity of employees, the character of the employer-employee relationship, and the like.46 However, because most of these typologies are developed from empirical research or metaresearch in Anglo-Saxon, lightly regulated environments, they underestimate the importance of regulatory challenges to successful human capital management in other contexts.47 To capture the primordial importance of the regulatory environment for Spanish firms’ human capital strategies, I take a different approach. Rather than develop a highly differentiated typology of strategies, I organize firms’ human resources objectives into just two categories—control or commitment. Following Arthur (1994), control strategies are those that manage people through the establishment of defined rules and objectives and close monitoring to ensure compliance. Commitment strategies are those that use human resource policies to encourage employees to identify with organizational goals and to provide them with the skills and tools they need to make decisions that advance the firm’s interests.48 This simplification allows me to focus attention on the variety of regulatory solutions pursued by firms seeking to put in place one or the other of these strategies.

sec.title: Four regulatory solutions to support human resource strategies
sec.p: I label the four regulatory solutions identified in the course of this research “sweating,” “compliance,” “individualization,” and “productivity coalitions.” Each solution defines a set of human resources practices that are designed to avoid, comply with, or leverage regulatory institutions (labor laws, collective bargaining agreements, worker representatives in the firm) in order to achieve greater productivity through compensation policies, internal flexibility, and motivation. The productivity-enhancing tactics associated with each of these solutions are described in Table 1 below.49 Sweating and compliance are regulatory solutions for firms whose human resources policies are built around a control strategy. Firms that seek to elicit greater worker commitment deploy individualization and productivity coalitions. Most firms combine elements from more than one of these regulatory solutions; however, most of their personnel and labor relations practices can be captured by just one. Each correlates with a set of beliefs about how the Spanish labor market functions and thus reflects firms’ particular preferences regarding labor market reforms.

sec.p: Sweating describes a low-road solution of increasing productivity through a variety of formally illegal but widely practiced tactics. Companies increase wage productivity by paying as little as possible, which can be achieved in several ways. Wages can be held in check by misusing temporary contracts, both by assigning temporary workers functions superior to the contracted classification and by potentially evading bonuses linked to job tenure. Firms also get more for less by paying workers a portion of their salary off the books—often achieving significant reductions in social security taxes—a practice that is common though obviously difficult to quantify.50 Finally, firms can push employees to work extra hours for little or no additional compensation, a practice that is widespread in many smaller and not a few larger firms.

Under the sweating model, internal flexibility (functional flexibility, workday flexibility) is achieved by avoiding clearly demarcated job definitions and by communicating the expectation that workers fulfill a variety of tasks as assigned. Workers are motivated to be more productive by the pervasive insecurity of their positions (layoffs of temporary workers or permanent ones with brief tenure are not expensive, especially when the formal salary on which indemnizations are based is very low) and by occasional offers of extra pay or better working conditions (e.g., better work assignments and schedules).

The sweating solution, particularly when it is applied in small firms, is hard to police from the outside, in Spain or anywhere else. However, the model is highly dependent on the existence of a strong buyer’s market for labor. In effect, recourse to sweating is the expression of an employer’s market power over and against formal institutions. Outside of large workplaces where labor inspections are relatively frequent, the application of formal Spanish labor market regulations rests mainly on the willingness of workers or their representatives to denounce illegal practices: where workers lack knowledge of their rights or believe that making a claim might entail the loss of their job in a context where few alternatives exist, they are unlikely to go to the authorities.51 Finally, if workers view certain practices that comprise the sweating model as normal, local worker representatives, where they exist, are also unlikely to denounce their employers because doing so may well create conflicts with their colleagues.
