sec.p: Sustaining the sweating solution is more difficult when the labor market turns in workers’ favor. This may be due either to general market conditions (higher demand for labor) or because workers’ specific skills are scarce. In the latter case, sweating may coexist with other types of employment relationships, depending on the type of worker involved. Under these conditions, sweating is effectively thwarted by labor market dynamics that give workers sufficient power either to demand that the law be adhered to or simply to change employers. Sweating is also more difficult to maintain as a firm grows, as unions and regulators are more likely to challenge such practices. However, decentralized operations and the absence of a works council may extend the viability of sweating by reducing the likelihood of random inspections and formal grievance claims. Employers who lose the market power that undergirds sweating practices discover that the regulatory framework in Spain does indeed have some bite, either through direct experience or, more likely, through conversations with other employers and, especially, financial and legal advisors.52 In many cases, the next step is the adoption of a solution I have labeled compliance.

The compliance solution is deployed largely by firms whose managers view personnel management as a broadly administrative matter and labor primarily as a cost to be contained. These perspectives follow seamlessly from an understanding of work organization as, in large measure, a technical problem to be solved through top-down control. For such firms, productivity is obtained by managing pay carefully—both to reduce costs and to align workers’ incentives with those of the firm. These firms are often obsessively conscious of the formal regulatory framework—the opportunities it generates as well as the limits it imposes. Firms with compliance-oriented HR policies complain bitterly about limitations on variable pay in collective bargaining agreements, unfair competition from smaller firms that are able to sweat their workers, and, above all, their inability to achieve internal flexibility without giving up something in return in sectoral, local, or individualized bargaining.

The current crisis means that many companies are ill-disposed, if not financially unable, to link individual or collective side payments to programs of work reorganization that fall under the definition of “substantial modifications” in the Workers’ Statute and thus may require either the assent of each affected worker or an agreement with worker representatives. At the same time, job insecurity generated by the crisis has sometimes increased workers’ willingness to accept changes without compensation when they believe that greater productivity and better work organization are truly keys to firm survival or their continuity in their jobs. However, for many firms that pursue compliance solutions, this argument is a tough sell: where the workplace culture has long held that firm strategy is strictly a management concern, employees are often skeptical about claims that work must be radically reorganized if the firm is to survive. This research documents that workers and their representatives often reject changes to pay, working conditions, and work organization even when jobs, including their own, are on the line.53

The limitations of the compliance solution are the mirror image of those identified for sweating. In each case, when economic conditions are favorable for employers, the solution offers a relatively straightforward path to greater internal and external flexibility. Compliance provides flexibility when economic growth is strong and firms have the resources to pay for it, whereas sweating works best when economic growth is low, jobs are scarce, and workers feel they have no better alternatives. In boom times, firms that practice sweating may be successful in moving toward compliance. On the other hand, employers who practice compliance may be tempted to pursue sweating when adversity strikes, but they will, at a minimum, face resistance from those workers whose positions are most consolidated—along with the possibility of complaints to the labor inspection service and fines. The formal dimensions of the Spanish regulatory framework (law, collective bargaining agreements, labor administration, and jurisprudence) do indeed pose obstacles to economic restructuring for firms that pursue compliance solutions as they seek to implement control-based human resources strategies.

Compliance is not, however, the only alternative to sweating pursued by Spanish employers; others take seriously the idea that human capital strategies can be a source of lasting competitive advantage, and that more committed and better qualified workers deliver superior results. Indeed, some of these firms have abandoned the compliance strategy precisely because they have discovered that it imposes substantial risks when firms face economic difficulties. We now turn to these alternatives.

The individualization solution finds its inspiration in Anglo-style human resources management. Managers in these firms often describe union leaders and works council members as fossilized “dinosaurs” committed to unmasking the supposed threat to workers’ rights contained in each and every employer initiative. They generally believe that the interests of motivated, capable workers can and should be aligned with those of the employer; for them, formal institutions of worker representation are nothing more than an obstacle to a more effective partnership between firms and their individual members. Indeed, more than one proponent of this approach has declared that, “the employees’ real representative here is the human resources department.”54

How do such firms define and navigate the obstacles to productivity they find in the existing regulatory framework? Whereas firms that adopt the compliance solution look to manipulate the institutional framework to their advantage, those that opt for individualization seek to reconstitute the terms of the employment relationship outside the framework of formal institutional rules. For example, many of these firms have largely renounced the use of temporary contracts: they believe that a generalized policy of permanent contracting from day one demonstrates the firm’s commitment to employee development and preempts the negative motivational consequences frequently associated with the change in status when workers move from temporary to permanent contracts. Similarly, many recent well-financed start-up ventures, some of which now employ hundreds of people, have made avoiding the creation of a works council a major priority.55 These firms select for fit as well as skill, rejecting candidates who identify with unions or fail to embrace a culture of meritocracy.

Where there is no works council, wage and internal flexibility are largely achieved through negotiations with individuals or work groups in which the sectoral collective bargaining agreement sets an effective floor for pay and an (at-best) loose reference for professional categories and working hours.56 Wages are typically somewhat higher than the sectoral collective bargaining agreement, and variable pay, whether collective or individual, may sometimes be a significant component of total compensation.57 These firms generally invest far more in training and development and nonwage benefits than those pursuing the compliance strategy, and they often devote considerable effort to identifying and grooming key personnel.

Where there is a works council, firms often adopt a blended strategy that mixes individualization wherever possible with compliance for many rank-and-file workers. Over the long years of economic growth during the 2000s, such firms tended to focus most of their human resources budgets on programs for their most valued professional staff. Negotiations with works councils were largely limited to discussions around issues where their input or consent was required by law. At the same time, many firms dedicated considerable effort to identifying activities that might “keep the works council busy and distracted.”58 Although such tactics may also be seen in some firms that pursue compliance, individualizers took their efforts a step further: they sought to isolate the works council and undermine its legitimacy with professional staff and (at a minimum) more skilled blue-collar workers through aggressive employee communications programs, individualized raises and nonconsolidating bonus payments, individualized training and development opportunities, and other types of social benefits. When, despite employers’ efforts to decouple the employment relationship from the formal institutional framework, workers or works councils resisted changes in hours and work organization by asserting their legal right to reject certain unilateral changes (modificaciones sustanciales), employers frequently responded by negotiating individual or group compensation to achieve their objectives. As we shall see in a moment, this particular aspect of the individualization solution would prove to be particularly vulnerable among firms whose economic fortunes took a turn for the worse with the current crisis.

The final regulatory solution observed in this study is the development of productivity coalitions.59 Productivity coalitions can be found in a broad variety of firms with all types of workforces. What these firms share is a management philosophy that places a premium on negotiation and transparency. In most cases, their human resources directors are lawyers or labor relations specialists; in others, labor relations are managed by a dedicated specialist who commands a great deal of authority both within the human resources area and with the heads of business units.60 In every case, the human resources area has a strong voice in the executive boardroom.

The managers of these firms believe that “unions and works councils have a legitimate role to play in society and in the firm.”61 This is not to say that they find it easy to work with works councils or union officials. Like their counterparts who are pursuing other solutions, these managers complain that worker representatives are often unreasonable in their demands and poorly prepared to understand the realities of the context in which the firms operate. However, unlike most of their counterparts, they believe that their mandate includes the development of workplace representatives’ understanding of the business, and, critically, ensuring that all line managers have the ability to engage these representatives.

These firms drive productivity by adjusting pay to reflect results, by frequently reorganizing tasks and work processes, and by motivating workers at all levels of the organization to be engaged in the search for ever-greater productivity. Stated in this fashion, the solution does not appear so different from that of individualization. Indeed, all of these firms pursue some variant of individualization with their senior professional staff. At the same time, however, they reject the notion that mere compliance is an effective approach to managing rank-and-file workers and their representatives.

The firms that build productivity coalitions share financial and operational data with workers and their representatives and dedicate substantial time and resources to ensuring that everyone (at least those on the works council) understands it. Although many larger firms offer operational managers a simplified introduction to the formal rules governing workplace relations, those pursuing productivity coalitions train operational managers how to engage worker representatives and build their support—or at least obtain their acquiescence—for the productivity-enhancing innovations they wish to implement.

sec.title: IV. The Political Implications of Strategic Choices in Human Capital Management
sec.p: Like their counterparts who pursue individualization, managers committed to building productivity coalitions aim to reconstitute the employment relationship; however, they look to do so within rather than outside of the formal institutional rules that govern the Spanish workplace. Are these simply alternative paths to greater productivity, or might there be reason to believe that one is superior to the other? Once again, we can ask how these solutions perform across the business cycle. As we saw above, neither sweating nor compliance appears to be a viable preferred solution in the Spanish context: the internal logic of each is likely to lead to its collapse at some point across the business cycle. What about individualization and productivity coalitions?

During our interviews, the most frequent solution we observed featured individualization for senior managers and a mix of both individualization and compliance practices with respect to rank-and-file workers, particularly in firms with works councils. On multiple occasions, managers from these firms claimed that the current economic crisis revealed serious shortcomings in the extant regulatory framework. Their complaints were largely focused around the obstacles to imposing unilaterally significant changes in work organization. Employers are no longer willing to purchase greater internal flexibility and have begun to argue that internal flexibility and changes in the structure of pay are critical to restoring profitability and saving jobs. On many occasions, however, workers and their representatives have resisted the changes employers seek by pulling the institutional levers provided by the existing legal framework (restrictions on unilateral changes in work organization [modificaciones sustanciales]; the automatic renewal of any collective bargaining clause that is not renegotiated [ultraactividad]; etc.).62

Firms that had attempted to build productivity coalitions were far less likely to voice these complaints. Every firm who pursued this solution noted that it required a long-term commitment to dialogue and education with workers and their representatives, patience in implementing changes, and a willingness to renounce certain objectives in order to reach consensus. At the same time, the longer firms sought to build productivity coalitions, the more goodwill they generated with workers—and the easier it became to make drastic changes quickly when the circumstances required it. None of these firms was totally satisfied with the regulatory framework, but all were convinced that it did not keep them from implementing the reforms they needed to compete effectively without relying on external flexibility alone. Indeed, three firms in our sample actually switched from individualization to a productivity coalition approach as the economic crisis unfolded—precisely because they were concerned about the robustness of compliance-oriented relations with their works councils at a time in which substantial restructuring was likely to be necessary.

Employers who pursue individualization generally do so not only because it is the dominant approach to managing human capital today, but also because they believe it is the solution that best enables them to overcome the rigidities they find in Spanish labor market regulations. As a rule, they define evading regulatory restrictions on managerial discretion as a central objective in human resources management and the key to workforce productivity, an argument underlying the reform proposals of mainstream economists. Managers in firms pursuing individualization were also likely to believe that the key to business success was the alignment of individual incentives of senior professionals with those of the firm. Most of their training budgets were targeted toward senior staff; productivity measures for rank-and-file personnel were often quite underdeveloped.63 These managers frequently defined worker representatives as “impossible to work with,” and as “only interested in themselves and totally disconnected from their colleagues.”64 Thus, when they discover that, in difficult times, individualization fails to offer a way around regulations, they find their prior assumptions about the labor market confirmed.

By contrast, employers who have built productivity coalitions find that they often are able to achieve the flexibility they need to maintain their edge in a rapidly changing competitive environment.65 Most of these employers believe, like most labor law scholars, that the Spanish regulatory framework ultimately requires firms with formal worker representatives to bargain in good faith and to seek win-win solutions for firms and their employees. They may not necessarily believe that this is the best way to regulate the employment relationship, but they are skeptical that a politically realistic alternative exists. Moreover, they often believe that radical changes in the current regulatory framework may well generate more problems than they would solve.66

What are the origins of these differences in beliefs? This survey is not sufficiently large to offer a definitive answer. However, the findings suggest a number of hypotheses. The most important source of different beliefs among our interview subjects appears to be education. Human resources directors who hold undergraduate degrees in law are more likely to pursue productivity coalition solutions than those who did not study law. These differences are reinforced by the nature of the managers’ postgraduate education. Productivity coalitions are often found in firms led by managers who studied in specialized human resources and labor relations masters programs in Spain; in rare exceptions the managers only hold an MBA.67 Productivity coalitions are particularly unlikely when the manager holds an MBA from an internationally prestigious program (whether the school was in Spain or abroad).

These results are not entirely surprising. Law school curriculums in Spain expose students to the principles defended by most labor law scholars as well as the formal institutional rules that encourage productivity coalitions. The faculties of most specialized masters programs in labor relations and human resources in Spain include a significant number of labor law scholars and professionals with substantial experience in collective bargaining, health and safety rules (which stipulate a major role for worker representatives in Spain), and conflict resolution. In programs more focused on labor relations, union officials, labor inspectors, and employer representatives are also likely to offer courses. Many of these professionals are sympathetic to the productivity coalition solution; at a minimum, they convey to their students that the Spanish regulatory framework makes managing collective employment relations a critical component of any successful human resources strategy. These academic and professional specializations—and the contents of the courses these professionals teach—are entirely absent from generalist business education at more elite programs in Spain and elsewhere. Those who did not study law and later took an MBA at one of these programs will have learned approaches to human resources management that are highly influenced by the individualistic, anti-union perspective that dominates the major U.S. business schools.68

This education effect appears to be robust across sectors, although a number of managers in the Spanish units of Anglo multinationals reported extreme difficulties in getting their global managers to appreciate the benefits of building productivity coalitions.69 Among Spanish companies, sectoral differences were observed according to the degree to which flexible organization has been historically important for tasks carried out by rank-and-file workers. It is not surprising that worker representatives’ capacities for organizing industrial action in a context of substantial formal rights to voice generated a culture of negotiation in firms where flexible work organization was key to competitiveness. Nevertheless, the limits of these sectoral differences—in particular, the existence of productivity coalition solutions in firms without a long history of labor conflict, a strong union presence, and activities far removed from traditional industries—suggest that beliefs inspired by education and workplace experiences are critical to explaining the variety of regulatory solutions observed across the sample.

Given that the vast majority of executives in Spain have studied in U.S.-inspired MBA programs, it is not surprising that the HR managers we interviewed described their senior management teams as being supportive of compliance or individualization solutions. However, we found that several HR managers were able to pursue productivity coalitions despite the preferences of senior management.70 This is likely attributable to the fact that decisions about the management of labor relations are often understood to be broadly technical matters left to specialists. If such specialists have a background in law, they are more likely to pursue productivity coalitions as they look to achieve the objectives set out for them by senior management. However, their ability to implement such solutions depends not only on their beliefs but also on their influence within the firm and, especially, their ability to incorporate training in labor relations (especially the management of relations with worker representatives) into development programs for mid-level managers.71

sec.title: Alternative explanations
sec.p: While very small firms can pursue sweating or individualization without much fear of serious regulatory problems, sweating is increasingly less viable as firm size increases. One of the central questions underlying this research then is why firms choose the regulatory solutions they do once they are too large to easily evade enforcement. My research reveals that the beliefs of key personnel overseeing the design and implementation of human capital policies—beliefs that are rooted in their educational and professional experiences—are perhaps the decisive factors in explaining the observed variety in employers’ regulatory solutions. In this section, I briefly review a number of alternative explanations.

A first alternative is that employers shift among regulatory solutions depending on structural factors such as changes in the business cycle or the nature of the challenges facing their particular sector. When times are bad, firms can impose compliance solutions while they count on the discipline of the market and recourse to temporary employment to minimize worker resistance. When labor markets turn favorable for workers, firms can shift to individualization strategies, purchasing the flexibility they need.72 One important finding of my research is that some firms that pursue this combination of compliance and individualization have shifted toward productivity coalition solutions in the face of extreme competitive difficulties. When they are unable to gain sufficient productivity through a combination of individualized negotiations with insiders and recourse to temporary employment, these employers have sought to transform the employment relationship through negotiated adjustment with worker representatives and more transparent communication with their entire staff. However, not all firms in such situations choose to pursue productivity coalitions. Moreover, my results reveal no consistent trends across sectors, with similarly placed firms in the same sector pursuing a variety of regulatory solutions.

Differences in workforce characteristics are another possible explanation for the variety of regulatory solutions observed. One commonly posited source of differences in firm strategies is the level of unionization. High rates of affiliation imply closer communication between workers and their local representatives, which, in principle, encourages greater sensitivity to individual workers’ concerns as well as greater capacity for organizing collective resistance to unilateral, employer-imposed changes.73 However, variations in affiliation rates do not dovetail closely with the regulatory solutions firms pursue. Some employers with well-organized and significantly unionized workforces seek to pursue productivity coalitions as a central tool for competitive adjustment, whereas other similarly placed firms label worker representatives “irresponsible” (and much worse) and do all they can to minimize their influence over employer decisions and their coworkers.

How might we explain this result? First, prior to the current crisis, both individualization and compliance strategies were relatively effective regulatory solutions for most larger employers. A combination of temporary contracting and the purchasing of whatever additional flexibility they required enabled most employers to adjust successfully while maintaining arm’s-length relations with worker representatives, regardless of the overall degree of workforce organization. Second, Spanish workers join unions for reasons that generally have little to do with voice at work.74 In a country with high rates of unemployment and precarious work, opportunities for permanent contracts are particularly scarce for youth in general and low- and medium-skilled workers in particular. Employers have often taken advantage of this fact in highly unionized firms by delegating to unions considerable control over hiring in exchange for their acquiescence to wage moderation or changes in shop-floor organization or working hours. Workers who seek to obtain employment for family and friends may often find unionization to be indispensible.75

Affiliation decisions are also frequently related to workplace conflicts, particularly layoffs. Where works councils are relatively innocuous bodies in firms that have pursued compliance or individualization strategies, worker representatives may not be up to the task of negotiating layoffs or significant changes in workplace organization. The conflicts and insecurity such situations generate are an important opportunity for sectoral union officials to gain a foothold in firms and, potentially, to attract new members. These types of union interventions often prove helpful in defusing tensions and may offer a bridge toward the building of productivity coalitions. Again, however, increases in unionization surrounding staff reductions do not automatically drive changes in employers’ choices of regulatory solutions.

Another potential factor favoring the emergence of productivity coalitions is the type of collective bargaining agreement that governs firm-level relations. The approximately 10 percent of workers whose employment relationship is governed by a firm-level collective bargaining agreement are overwhelmingly located in larger firms where affiliation rates are often much higher than average.76 Does the existence of a firm-level agreement imply a greater propensity to pursue productivity coalitions?

There is no reason to believe this is the case. Until the reform of collective bargaining in 2011, sectoral collective bargaining agreements could provide obligatory content for firm-level agreements regarding critical questions such as contracting and job categories, geographic mobility, and the like.77 Since 1994 employers have been able to modify the distribution of working hours, shifts, compensation systems, work organization, and productivity targets as stipulated in a collective bargaining agreement, a formal or informal pact, or by custom if (and only if) changes can be negotiated successfully with the works council or subsequently approved through mediation or arbitration.78 If the changes affect individual arrangements, workers have recourse in the courts and the right to an indemnization of up to nine months salary if they refuse the change. Opting out of established wage rates has been theoretically negotiable but in reality extremely difficult to implement except in the most drastic of circumstances.

As a consequence, firm-level collective bargaining agreements offer employers few advantages over sectoral agreements. In fact, many firm-level agreements originate in labor conflicts motivated by workers’ demands for pay or working conditions that improve on sectoral agreements. Moreover, rules governing the renewal of collective bargaining agreements may actually discourage collaboration. Spanish labor law requires the automatic renewal of any collective bargaining clauses (including significant changes in workplace organization and job assignments) when both sides do not agree to renegotiate. As a result, even local worker representatives in highly organized workplaces have few incentives to initiate dialogue with employers regarding the transformation of workplace organization. In such a context, it is not surprising that employers have often preferred to restrict collective discussions over workplace changes to those few issues that cannot be handled any other way (i.e., through unilateral imposition of changes or through individual side payments).

Some employers indicated that they preferred sectoral collective agreements to firm-level ones because they believed that workplace conflict would be reduced when workers and their local representatives were less directly involved in negotiations. Although such firms may prefer to negotiate changes with respect to the sectoral agreement individually, the magnitude of the desired changes may make this approach impossible (particularly when the changes would affect significant numbers of workers or deliver more flexibility than permitted in the sectoral agreement). Moreover, with issues such as the size of salary increases and overall hours at least partially resolved at the sectoral level, these firms may find it easier to negotiate other issues such as changes in work organization with local representatives; in other words, a case can be made that productivity coalitions may be easier to negotiate when the relevant collective bargaining agreement is sectoral rather than local.79

If productivity coalitions are not clearly linked to affiliation rates or the level of collective bargaining, perhaps they are related to employee skill levels? The results do not support this hypothesis. Regardless of skill level, firms that reach a certain size face significant regulatory obstacles to pursuing unilateral control or commitment strategies at some point in the business cycle. I have identified productivity coalitions in low-skill sectors such as food and beverage and construction and in high-skill sectors like engineering, banking, and pharmaceuticals. I have also identified firms in all of these sectors that fail to pursue such solutions even when faced with severe competitive pressures and acknowledged shortcomings in internal labor flexibility.

Finally, the emergence of productivity coalitions could be linked to the age of the firm. Perhaps younger firms have been able to build workplace cultures that are more integrative than the paternalistic or arm’s-length cultures that have long dominated Spanish workplaces?80 Anecdotal evidence (including two firms in this study) suggests that a small number of businesses created from the 1990s onward have sought to prevent the creation of works councils or union sections in their firms through a combination of careful selection processes and an intensive commitment to human resources management techniques. Such employers avoid publicizing their efforts to avoid the attention of unions and, perhaps, competitors. However, the small number of firms of which we have direct knowledge have relatively highly skilled, youthful workforces and have managed to weather the current crisis reasonably well. It is not clear whether such strategies are robust enough to withstand a protracted crisis in which workers are asked to do more and more in exchange for less and less.

sec.title: The political significance of employer beliefs
sec.p: The differences in employers’ interpretations of labor market obstacles and in their preferred solutions to these challenges as described in this article have broad political implications. Almost all observers agree that Spain’s OECD-leading rate of temporary employment is a drag on productivity and a potential threat to political and social stability. However, the policy prescriptions that follow from the belief that high rates of precarious employment are a product of excessive protections for permanent workers are quite different from those implied by the belief that precarious employment is the product of employers’ ideologically motivated reluctance to engage worker representatives sufficiently. Similarly, empirical studies demonstrate that Spanish firms have failed to pursue internal flexibility with the intensity of many of their European counterparts, leading to an overreliance on adjustment through levels of employment.81 Again, the policy prescriptions that follow from this data will vary significantly depending on whether one views this as a problem of legal rigidity or of employers’ reluctance to negotiate.

This article’s exploration of the limits of four different regulatory solutions across the business cycle implies an alternative hypothesis regarding the causes of high temporary employment in Spain, one with important policy implications. As we have seen, only productivity coalitions have proven to be a robust solution across sectors and business cycles. However, only a small minority of firms has pursued this strategy until now. In times of rapid economic growth, most firms were able to achieve adequate levels of financial performance through compliance or individualization (or some combination of the two). The cushion of temporary employment on which both of these solutions rests was made possible by the 1984 labor market reforms put in place by the Socialist government of Felipe González. This reform greatly facilitated temporary contracting while leaving legal restrictions on internal flexibility largely in place. In 1994, the last González government passed a new round of labor market reforms that significantly expanded the possibilities for negotiated internal flexibility. Critically, however, the Spanish economy was already recovering from the crisis of the early 1990s at the time of this reform and continued to grow at a rapid pace until the current crisis brought the boom to a screeching halt in the second half of 2007.

From 1984 to the present, temporary employment in Spain remained extraordinarily high in cross-national terms. This anomaly appears less surprising when this timeline of policy reforms is mapped against the evolution of economic cycles and the human capital strategies described in this article. From 1984 to 1994, the productivity coalition solution was significantly constrained by labor market rules that limited internal flexibility. By the time these legal restrictions were relaxed ten years later, most firms were already adept at finding ways to gain internal and wage flexibility through external flexibility (i.e., temporary contracting). Although these strategies may not have been the most efficient, the productivity costs involved were clearly acceptable for most firms during the long boom that was already nascent in 1994. As a result, the options for negotiated flexibility solutions that the 1994 reform put in place went largely unused outside that small minority of firms that has pursued productivity coalitions.

Now that the productivity costs implied by the interaction between the extant regulatory framework and the dominant regulatory solutions pursued by Spanish firms are clearly too high to bear, the question of regulatory reform is once again front and center. Is there an alternative to the neoliberal prescription of more relaxed contracting rules for all workers, both permanent and temporary, and greater employer discretion with respect to internal work rules?

The success of productivity coalitions suggests that such an alternative already exists. This argument is reinforced by recent analyses of the German case, which show that legal restrictions on external flexibility and political opposition to pursuing more orthodox neoliberal reforms have pushed employers and workers to find new, more flexible solutions internally. Critically, the solutions that have restored German economic growth were forged in the context of a long crisis that gave rise to a rapid increase in temporary employment, not unlike the one in which Spain now finds itself.82

What would happen if the institutional incentives favoring productivity coalitions in Spain were to be overturned? Given that ideological opposition to this strategy is extremely widespread within the Spanish managerial class, such regulatory solutions would likely disappear from all but the most highly unionized firms. If comprehensive reforms of labor market rules were to generate a substantial increase in employment, this might, on average, be a good deal for Spanish workers. However, such an outcome is far from certain; and, as the research presented in this article makes clear, such reforms would almost certainly undermine the possibilities for industrial democracy in most Spanish workplaces.83 Spanish employers, as this research has shown, can pursue competitive adjustment without evading the incentives to dialogue that are embodied in existing regulations. That many choose not to do so is a weak argument for the radical reform of existing institutions, both in Spain and anywhere else where the institutional protections for workers’ rights are currently under broad assault.

sec.title: V. Conclusion
sec.p: The variety of strategic solutions described in this article speaks eloquently to the fact that human capital strategy choices are driven not only by the quest for competitive advantage but also by beliefs about how the world of work can and should be organized—beliefs about the appropriate balance of power as well as the character of the relationship between employers and workers. These beliefs play a powerful role in determining how employers understand and respond to institutional incentives; that is, they are a critical intervening variable between formal rules and the politics of work in the firm. This fact is particularly relevant in densely regulated labor markets like Spain’s and those of most other Continental European countries. Here, the success of a firm’s human capital strategy depends not only on its ability to motivate workers but also on its robustness in the face of institutional obstacles across the business cycle.

Given the limits of the sample and the qualitative nature of the survey, this article does not pretend to draw conclusions regarding the degree to which specific institutional reforms may improve the aggregate performance of the Spanish labor market. It does provide, however, a useful correction to arguments that Spanish labor market institutions condemn firms to uncompetitively low levels of labor productivity. Spanish firms’ excessive reliance on temporary contracting as a strategy for achieving internal—as well as external—flexibility is not only a response to institutional incentives but also a product of their beliefs about the obstacles to obtaining internal flexibility through other means.

Because institutional incentives are often ambiguous, and even contradictory, beliefs play a critical role in guiding actors’ responses to the rules and regulations that are intended to shape their behavior. It is therefore vital that we understand their origins. My research suggests that education can play a crucial role in shaping employers’ beliefs regarding labor market institutions and, thus, their responses to the human capital challenges they face.

The debate about labor market rigidities in Spain is thus not merely, or even primarily, a technical one: it is a battle for advantage in markets and in politics; it is a contest among contrasting visions regarding the appropriate balance between efficiency and equity concerns, between individual and collective rights, at work and in society as a whole. As we have seen, individualization and productivity coalitions—both solutions to the challenge of gaining greater commitment from rank-and-file workers—provide very different levels of collective voice to workers. Absent institutional incentives to collective participation, few managers in Spain would offer it: if the regulatory framework is changed to facilitate the unilateral imposition of greater internal flexibility by employers, then productivity coalitions are likely to become few and far between. Critically, as I have noted, the firms that rely on individualization as a regulatory solution to achieve worker commitment do so not because they cannot pursue productivity coalitions, but rather because they prefer not do to so. In other words, the first principle of equity and collective voice at work underlying much of Spanish labor market regulation is not so much economically obsolete as it is politically anathema to many employers.

The cause of equity can, of course, hardly be well served by Spain’s OECD-leading levels of unemployment and temporary contracting. However, as this research shows, institutions that promote worker voice are hardly an insurmountable obstacle to workplace productivity. The micro- (and macro-) political implications of proposals for institutional reform that involve the effective abandonment of core principles such as worker voice therefore deserve far more careful reflection and debate than they have received to date. Those who seek to preserve (or abandon) these principles should also remember that shaping beliefs is at least as important as shaping legislation in their struggle to achieve their objectives.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Kenneth A. Dubin (ken.dubin@uc3m.es) is visiting professor in the department of Social Law, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid (Spain) and adjunct professor in Strategy and Human Resources, IE Business School (Spain). He is currently working on a comparative study on the role of labor market regulations and labor market intermediaries in the development of firm strategies in nonliberal market economies. He holds a PhD in political science from the University of California, Berkeley.
